item.title: Euler's number
item.description: Introduction If you ask someone to define \(\pi\), they will tell you that it is the ratio of the length of a circumference to its radius. If you ask them to define \(e\) though, they may ask you for a piece of paper and a pen, and then write one of the following expresions: $$e = \sum_{n = 0}^{\infty}{\frac{1}{n!}} \hspace{50pt} e = \lim_{x \to 0} \left( 1 + x \right)^{1/x}$$
